projects.title: BibleFlow
projects.description: Swift mobile application for offline Bible reading, multilingual, for iOS and macOS.
projects.detail: BibleFlow is a Swift mobile application designed to provide a complete Bible reading experience without an internet connection. It supports multiple languages for biblical texts, an adaptive interface running on iOS and macOS, and smooth navigation between books, chapters, and verses. The app focuses on accessibility and offline performance. Currently in development, the project includes management of different translations, local storage of Bible versions, and a modern responsive UI based on SwiftUI (or UIKit), with future features such as search, favorites, annotations, and data synchronization between devices.

projects.title: BTCpay Server â€“ Crypto Payments
projects.description: Deployment of a self-hosted BTCpay server to accept cryptocurrency payments (BTC, XMR, LTC, DOGE, DASH) in a sovereign, secure, and intermediary-free way.
projects.detail: Setup of BTCpay Server on an on-prem Debian server via Docker, with a secure reverse proxy and protected remote access. Configuration of wallets for multiple cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin, Monero, Litecoin, Dogecoin, Dash), dynamic invoice generation, integration of a full node for each, and local key management without trusted third parties. This project strengthens financial autonomy and puts into practice advanced concepts of decentralization, security, and digital sovereignty. Special attention is given to infrastructure resilience, network security, and user experience for both merchant and client.

projects.title: Personal HomeLab
projects.description: Deployment of a complete HomeLab on Debian server with AI, DevOps, virtualization, and security services via private VPN.
projects.detail: Installation and configuration of a Debian server on a recycled physical machine to host a personal HomeLab via CasaOS. Setup of Tailscale for secure and encrypted remote access. Deployment and management of advanced services via Docker: local AI chatbot (Ollama CPU + Open WebUI), development environment (VSCode Server), productivity tools (Ghostfolio, Wallos, LibreTranslate, Stirling PDF, ConvertX, IT Tools), media player (Navidrome), remote desktop (Webtop), and a custom YouTube Downloader. Centralized logging via Dozzle. All services are containerized, isolated, and accessible only via VPN. This project implements best practices in system administration, network security, virtualization, and DevOps, while leveraging modern self-hosting tools.

projects.title: Automated Trading Bot
projects.description: Development of a crypto trading bot using Freqtrade, a custom DCA strategy, and a UI accessible via Cloudflare Tunnel.
projects.detail: Creation of an automated trading bot based on Freqtrade, integrating an advanced DCA (Dollar-Cost Averaging) strategy optimized for a minimum annual return of 15%. The bot monitors market trends and applies smart buy and sell orders based on technical indicators. Performance was validated via backtests over several years: 2022 (15.05%), 2023 (17.83%), and 2024 (16.42%). The application is deployed on an on-premise Linux server, ensuring full control over the infrastructure. Virtualization via Docker ensures optimal service isolation and facilitates updates and scalability. A user interface via Freqtrade UI allows real-time monitoring of open positions, performance, and transaction history. A Cloudflare tunnel was set up to secure remote access to the interface and ensure smooth bot management without direct Internet exposure.

projects.title: Portfolio Website
projects.description: Creation of an interactive portfolio to showcase my work.
projects.detail: Development of an interactive website to present my professional and personal projects. The site is hosted on Azure Static Web Apps for optimal performance and simplified deployment management. The domain name is managed by Infomaniak. A custom routing service in pure JavaScript is used for smooth navigation between the site's sections and to ensure the Single Page Application principle. The design is minimalist and modern thanks to picoCSS.

projects.title: Swifty-Companion
projects.description: iOS application in SwiftUI using the 42 API to display information about a student.
projects.detail: Swifty-Companion is a mobile project developed as part of 42 school. It is an iOS application built with SwiftUI that consumes the official 42 API via OAuth2 (Intranet) to dynamically display user data. The app features a home view with a search field (42 login), a student profile view (login, level, location in the school, coalition, completed projects, skills, profile picture), a reactive architecture adapted to multiple screen sizes, and robust error handling (login not found, API unavailable, network or authentication issues). Bonus features include OAuth2 token refresh on expiration and automatic reconnection if the mandatory part is perfect. All security best practices are followed, including ignoring the .env file for API keys.

projects.title: Inception of Things
projects.description: Introductory project to Kubernetes with Vagrant, K3s, K3d, and GitOps (Argo CD), developed as part of 42 school.
projects.detail: This project aims to become familiar with Kubernetes from a developer's perspective. It starts by creating one or more virtual machines with Vagrant (part 1). Next, a K3s cluster is deployed and several applications are run with an Ingress (part 2). The final step involves K3d combined with Argo CD to set up continuous integration/continuous deployment directly from a GitHub repository (part 3). An optional bonus part consists of integrating GitLab + CI/CD with Argo CD to automatically synchronize applications on the cluster.

projects.title: Cloud-1
projects.description: Implementation of a complete WordPress environment with Docker Compose on Azure.
projects.detail: This project consists of creating a complete WordPress environment using Docker containers for WordPress, MariaDB, phpMyAdmin, and Nginx, deployed on an Azure VM. Containers are orchestrated with Docker Compose and automated via Ansible for deployment and configuration. The environment uses SSL certificates to secure connections and ensures data persistence for MariaDB and WordPress.

projects.title: Libft
projects.description: Recreate the main functions of the C standard library.
projects.detail: Development of a personal library by recreating several essential functions of the C standard library, focusing on best practices and efficient memory management.

projects.title: Get Next Line
projects.description: Read a line from a file efficiently.
projects.detail: Creation of a function capable of reading line by line from a file or standard input, using buffers to optimize performance.

projects.title: Ft_printf
projects.description: Reproduce the printf function from the C standard library.
projects.detail: Development of a custom version of the printf function, supporting multiple formats and specifications, while efficiently managing memory.

projects.title: Born2BeRoot
projects.description: Configure a secure virtual machine.
projects.detail: Installation and configuration of a secure virtual machine based on Debian. This project covers several essential aspects of system management, including downloading and installing the VM, initial configuration, SSH connection, and setting up strict security policies. Concepts include virtualization with VirtualBox, permissions and user management, installation and configuration of essential services like SSH and UFW, as well as setting up robust password policies and security logs.

projects.title: Push_Swap
projects.description: Implement a sorting algorithm with a limited number of operations.
projects.detail: The push_swap project consists of developing a C program that takes a list of integers as command-line arguments and displays a sequence of operations to sort these integers optimally. The program uses two stacks, 'a' and 'b', and a limited set of stack manipulation operations to sort the integers. Allowed operations include swaps, rotations, and pushes between stacks. The goal is to minimize the total number of operations performed to sort the stack.

projects.title: Minitalk
projects.description: Creation of a client-server application to exchange messages via Unix signals.
projects.detail: Development of a simple client-server communication system using Unix signals as the transmission medium. The client sends a message to the server, which receives and displays it. The client converts each character of the message into a sequence of bits and sends them to the server using SIGUSR1 and SIGUSR2 signals. The server reconstructs the message from the received bits and displays it. The server confirms receipt of each message by sending a signal to the client. The project also includes bonus features such as Unicode character support.

projects.title: So_Long
projects.description: Development of a 2D game in C based on a graphics library.
projects.detail: Welcome to So_Long, a 2D game project developed in C as part of a programming learning program. This project focuses on creating a simple game using the MinilibX graphics library. The goal is to build a game where a player moves through a map, collects objects, avoids obstacles, and reaches the exit. The game involves handling user input, graphics rendering, and managing game elements such as the player, objects, obstacles, and the exit. The project includes event handling, animations, and interactions with the environment.

projects.title: Philosophers
projects.description: Simulation of a classic multithreading algorithm problem.
projects.detail: This program implements the simulation of the classic dining philosophers problem using threads and mutexes in C. The simulation involves philosophers alternating between eating, thinking, and sleeping. They use forks to eat and put them back on the table when finished. Philosophers must never starve, and the simulation stops when a philosopher dies of starvation. The program must be written without using global variables and must take arguments such as the number of philosophers, time limits for eating, sleeping, and dying, as well as an optional argument for the number of meals each philosopher must have before the simulation ends. The program must also handle event logging and ensure philosophers avoid dying. The program can be implemented with either threads and mutexes or processes and semaphores (in my case, threads & mutexes).

projects.title: Minishell
projects.description: Creation of a minimalist shell inspired by Bash.
projects.detail: In our 'Minishell' project at 42 school, we develop a simplified shell program. This challenge is crucial for our understanding of processes and file descriptors. Our goal is to create a minimalist version of bash, immersing ourselves in the nuances of shell programming. We focus on fundamental aspects such as command input handling, file directory manipulation, environment variable interpretation, and implementing essential features like signal handling and command execution. This project represents an important step towards a deep understanding of system programming, offering practical experience with key concepts used in Unix/Linux shell environments.

projects.title: Cub3D
projects.description: Development of a 3D game inspired by Wolfenstein 3D with ray-casting.
projects.detail: This project consists of creating a first-person 3D game using the ray-casting technique to render a maze. The game is developed with the MiniLibX graphics library and includes features such as player movement, shooting, and texture management.

projects.title: NetPractice
projects.description: Learning the fundamental concepts of networking.
projects.detail: The NetPractice project is an exciting challenge offered by 42 school that aims to deepen and put into practice my skills in computer networking. This project is a unique opportunity for me to dive into the complex and fascinating world of networks, learning to manipulate, configure, and troubleshoot in real and simulated network environments. Objectives include understanding networking fundamentals, including OSI and TCP/IP models, mastering the configuration and management of network devices such as switches and routers, and applying troubleshooting techniques to identify and resolve network issues.

projects.title: C++ Pool (part.1)
projects.description: Introduction to object-oriented programming in C++.
projects.detail: Discovering the basics of object-oriented programming with C++. Focus on classes, objects, and modularity. Understanding ad-hoc polymorphism, overloads, and orthodox canonical classes in C++. Learning about memory allocation, references, member pointers, and using switch in C++. Exploring C++ specifics compared to C, with a dive into object-oriented programming. Study of subtype polymorphism, abstract classes, and interfaces in C++. Understanding inheritance in C++ and its implications for designing robust and modular software.

projects.title: C++ Pool (part.2)
projects.description: Deepening advanced C++ concepts.
projects.detail: Deepening advanced C++ features such as templates, different types of casts, use of standard containers (STL), template containers, iterators and algorithms, as well as exception handling with Try/Catch blocks. The project also includes implementing generic programming concepts, handling smart pointers, and optimizing performance through advanced memory management techniques.

projects.title: Inception
projects.description: Deployment of a complex and secure web infrastructure with Docker.
projects.detail: As part of our curriculum at 42 school, we tackle the project called 'Inception'. This ambitious project is part of a process to deepen and apply knowledge acquired in virtualization and container management. Our goal is to deploy a complex and secure infrastructure, fully configured using Docker and orchestrated by docker-compose, all within a dedicated virtual machine. The architecture includes several key components: a Docker container with NGINX, a container dedicated to WordPress + php-fpm, a container for MariaDB, two separate volumes for the database and website files, and a specific Docker network for inter-container communication. Containers must be built from custom Dockerfiles, without using prebuilt Docker images or services like DockerHub.

projects.title: Webserv
projects.description: Implementation of a web server in C++ following the HTTP protocol.
projects.detail: The Webserv project at 42 school consists of implementing a web server in C++ to the C++98 standard. This server must be able to serve static files and handle CGI requests. It must also handle multiple simultaneous connections, large files asynchronously and non-blockingly. Additionally, the server must support HTTP GET, POST, and DELETE methods, as well as CGI requests for GET and POST. It must be able to handle errors and return appropriate HTTP status codes. The server must also handle requests with large headers and bodies, with a limit defined in the configuration file. The reference behavior for this project is Nginx.

projects.title: Ft_Transcendence
projects.description: Development of a complete web application for an online multiplayer game.
projects.detail: Creation of a web platform for a real-time multiplayer game, including WebSocket. The project includes user management, local and remote multiplayer support, a tournament system, statistics boards, and advanced security measures such as password hashing and protection against XSS/SQL Injection attacks. The backend is managed by a custom Web module, the database is integrated, and the frontend uses JavaScript with a modern toolkit. The application is a SPA compatible with Chrome, without console errors, and launches with a single command.

projects.title: Shell Modules
projects.description: Introduction to shell scripts and Unix command management.
projects.detail: This project explores the basics of shell scripting, essential Unix commands, and their use in a Linux environment. The goal is to learn how to automate common tasks.

projects.title: C Modules
projects.description: First basics of the C language, logic and simple algorithms.
projects.detail: Learning the basics of the C language, including data structures, loops, and functions. The projects also emphasize algorithmic logic and compilation tools.

projects.title: Rushes
projects.description: Intensive team challenges to solve complex problems.
projects.detail: Collaborative work on complex challenges with short deadlines, aiming to improve problem-solving skills and team communication.
